importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The decision to postpone the adoption of the Net Zero Framework was made on this date, following President Trump’s public threat and a subsequent vote in London.
The Net Zero Framework was originally approved by the IMO in April 2025, setting the groundwork for a global carbon-pricing system targeting shipping emissions.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework was delayed until late 2026, marking a 12-month postponement due to U.S. political opposition.

keyTakeAways: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months after President Donald Trump threatened sanctions on countries supporting the plan.
The Net Zero Framework would have established the first global carbon-pricing system in shipping, charging ships $380 per metric tonne of CO2-equivalent emissions.
The framework aims to reduce shipping emissions by 20% by 2030 and eliminate them by 2050, aligning with global climate goals.
Countries like China, the European Union, Brazil, Britain, and Argentina initially supported the plan, but Argentina and Singapore changed their stance to postpone implementation.
Russia and Saudi Arabia opposed the measure, calling it politically driven or environmentally unfeasible.
Trump’s threat to impose sanctions, visa restrictions, and port levies on supporting nations significantly influenced the IMO’s vote dynamics.
The International Chamber of Shipping expressed concern over lack of clarity for industry investments in decarbonization.
Vanuatu’s climate minister called the delay 'unacceptable' given accelerating climate change and emphasized the importance of international law.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The International Maritime Organization (IMO) postponed the formal adoption of the Net Zero Framework (NZF) by at least 12 months after U.S. President Donald Trump threatened to impose sanctions on countries supporting the plan. The NZF, which would have introduced a $380 per metric tonne carbon tax on shipping emissions, was originally approved in April 2025. Despite broad international support from nations including China, the EU, Brazil, and Britain, the vote shifted due to political pressure from the United States. Countries like Argentina and Singapore also changed their stance, voting to postpone implementation. The delay undermines global progress toward reducing shipping emissions, which contribute significantly to climate change, and raises concerns from climate advocates and the shipping industry about lack of clarity and investment risk. The decision marks a setback in international climate cooperation and highlights the influence of fossil fuel-aligned politics on global environmental policy.
title: Trump torpedoes international deal to reduce shipping emissions
